elements.content: The first 3D coordination polymer containing a nucleobase as a bridging ligand, {[Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2][Cu(ox)(H2O)]2·∼14H2O} n (1), has been synthesized by reaction of adenine (Hade) with a basic solution of K2[Cu(ox)2]·2H2O (ox = oxalato dianion). Compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̄ with a = b = 31.350(1) Å, c = 14.285(1) Å, V = 12158.7(10) Å3, and Z = 9. X-ray analysis shows a covalent 3D network in which the copper(II) centers are bridged by tridentate μ-N3,N7,N9 adeninate ligands. The compound has relatively large, nanometer-sized tubes associated with the self-assembly process directed solely by metal−ligand interactions. The covalent 3D framework remains intact upon removal of the guest water molecules trapped in the nanotubes. Magnetic measurements indicate an overall antiferromagnetic behavior of the compound.
elements.clean_text: The first 3D coordination polymer containing a nucleobase as a bridging ligand, {[Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2][Cu(ox)(H2O)]2⋅~14H2O} n  (1), has been synthesized by reaction of adenine (Hade) with a basic solution of K2[Cu(ox)2]⋅2H2O (ox = oxalato dianion). Compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̄ with a = b = 31.350(1) Å, c = 14.285(1) Å, V = 12158.7(10) Å3, and Z = 9. X-ray analysis shows a covalent 3D network in which the copper(II) centers are bridged by tridentate μ-N3,N7,N9 adeninate ligands. The compound has relatively large, nanometer-sized tubes associated with the self-assembly process directed solely by metal-ligand interactions. The covalent 3D framework remains intact upon removal of the guest water molecules trapped in the nanotubes. Magnetic measurements indicate an overall antiferromagnetic behavior of the compound.

elements.content: The compound {[Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2][Cu(ox)(H2O)]2·∼14H2O} n shows an unprecedent covalent 3D network constructed from a nucleobase (adenine) as the bridging ligand. The adeninate bridges exhibit an unusual μ-N3,N7,N9 coordination mode for unsubstituted adenine complexes. The autoassembly process of the structural units generates nanochannels filled by crystallization water molecules. Thermogravimetric and XRPD analyses reveal that the solvent molecules can be evacuated from the pores without loss of the framework periodicity. Magnetic measurements indicate a moderate antiferromagnetic coupling among the copper(II) centers.
elements.clean_text: The compound {[Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2][Cu(ox)(H2O)]2⋅~14H2O} n  shows an unprecedent covalent 3D network constructed from a nucleobase (adenine) as the bridging ligand. The adeninate bridges exhibit an unusual μ-N3,N7,N9 coordination mode for unsubstituted adenine complexes. The autoassembly process of the structural units generates nanochannels filled by crystallization water molecules. Thermogravimetric and XRPD analyses reveal that the solvent molecules can be evacuated from the pores without loss of the framework periodicity. Magnetic measurements indicate a moderate antiferromagnetic coupling among the copper(II) centers.

elements.content: Crystal engineering of high-dimensional frameworks from the self-assembly of transition metal complexes is one of the most challenging issues in current synthetic chemistry, not only because of their intrinsic aesthetic appeal but also because of their potentially exploitable properties. Previous studies have demonstrated that the most efficient approach to construct this type of material is to use the covalent linkages provided by multidentate organic ligands and/or to utilize the hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking capabilities of suitable multifunctional ligands. The judicious choice of the organic ligands is a key step in designing multidimensional framework compounds containing transition metal complexes as building blocks.
elements.clean_text: Crystal engineering of high-dimensional frameworks from the self-assembly of transition metal complexes is one of the most challenging issues in current synthetic chemistry, not only because of their intrinsic aesthetic appeal but also because of their potentially exploitable properties. Previous studies have demonstrated that the most efficient approach to construct this type of material is to use the covalent linkages provided by multidentate organic ligands and/or to utilize the hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking capabilities of suitable multifunctional ligands. The judicious choice of the organic ligands is a key step in designing multidimensional framework compounds containing transition metal complexes as building blocks.

elements.content: The unsubstituted adenine nucleobase contains at least five donor sites (N9, N7, N3, N1, and N10) capable of coordinating metallic ions, and its versatility as a ligand is well-known. The crystal structures of nearly 60 adenine transition metal complexes have been retrieved from the Cambridge structural database (CSD, Jan 2004 release), and 11 different metal-ion binding patterns have been found. Transition metal complexes containing nucleobases have been extensively studied as biomimetic systems with the aim of analyzing the role of the noncovalent interactions (hydrogen bonds and π−π stackings) that are operative in the conformation and function of macromolecular biological systems. These complexes have also been used to investigate the DNA−metal binding processes that are essential in the development of new biologically active metallodrugs.
elements.clean_text: The unsubstituted adenine nucleobase contains at least five donor sites (N9, N7, N3, N1, and N10) capable of coordinating metallic ions, and its versatility as a ligand is well-known. The crystal structures of nearly 60 adenine transition metal complexes have been retrieved from the Cambridge structural database (CSD, Jan 2004 release), and 11 different metal-ion binding patterns have been found. Transition metal complexes containing nucleobases have been extensively studied as biomimetic systems with the aim of analyzing the role of the noncovalent interactions (hydrogen bonds and π-π stackings) that are operative in the conformation and function of macromolecular biological systems. These complexes have also been used to investigate the DNA-metal binding processes that are essential in the development of new biologically active metallodrugs.

elements.content: Most of these compounds are monomers or discrete polymeric species of low nuclearity in which the supramolecular 3D structure is achieved by means of noncovalent interactions. The number of n-dimensional (nD, n = 1−3) coordination polymers based only on the covalent interactions of a purine nucleobase is small. To our knowledge, this field is limited to some 1D complexes containing purine as terminal or bridging ligands.
elements.clean_text: Most of these compounds are monomers or discrete polymeric species of low nuclearity in which the supramolecular 3D structure is achieved by means of noncovalent interactions. The number of n-dimensional (nD, n = 1-3) coordination polymers based only on the covalent interactions of a purine nucleobase is small. To our knowledge, this field is limited to some 1D complexes containing purine as terminal or bridging ligands.

elements.content: We report herein the synthesis, crystal structure, thermal behavior, and magnetic properties of the first example of a covalent 3D network containing adenine as a bridging ligand, the porous coordination polymer {[Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2][Cu(ox)(H2O)]2·∼14H2O} n (1).
elements.clean_text: We report herein the synthesis, crystal structure, thermal behavior, and magnetic properties of the first example of a covalent 3D network containing adenine as a bridging ligand, the porous coordination polymer {[Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2][Cu(ox)(H2O)]2⋅~14H2O} n  (1).

elements.content: The X-ray crystal structure analysis14 revealed the presence of a unique 3D framework with two distinct types of neutral building blocks:  dimeric [Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2] units and mononuclear [Cu(ox)(H2O)] entities. A perspective view of a fragment of the polymeric structure is given in Figure , together with selected bond lengths. The labeling scheme used here for the nucleobase is that conventionally accepted for chemical and biological purposes.
elements.clean_text: The X-ray crystal structure analysis14 revealed the presence of a unique 3D framework with two distinct types of neutral building blocks: dimeric [Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2] units and mononuclear [Cu(ox)(H2O)] entities. A perspective view of  a fragment of the polymeric structure is given in Figure , together with selected bond lengths. The labeling scheme used here for the nucleobase is that conventionally accepted for chemical and biological purposes.

elements.content: ORTEP view of a fragment of the polymeric network of1 (30% probability thermal ellipsoids). H atoms are omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances (Å):  Cu1−N3a, 2.000(8); Cu1−N9ai, 2.013(7); Cu1−N3b, 2.014(8); Cu1−N9bi, 2.003(7); Cu1−O1w, 2.172(6); Cu2−O1, 1.953(6); Cu2−O2, 1.930(6); Cu2−N7aii, 1.985(7); Cu2−N7b, 1.997(7); Cu2−O2w, 2.317(7). Symmetry codes:  (i) −x + 1, −y, −z; (ii) −y + 1/3, x − y − 1/3, z − 1/3.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP view of a fragment of the polymeric network of1 (30% probability thermal ellipsoids). H atoms are omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances (Å): Cu1-N3a, 2.000(8); Cu1-N9ai, 2.013(7); Cu1-N3b, 2.014(8); Cu1-N9bi, 2.003(7); Cu1-O1w, 2.172(6); Cu2-O1, 1.953(6); Cu2-O2, 1.930(6); Cu2-N7aii, 1.985(7); Cu2-N7b, 1.997(7); Cu2-O2w, 2.317(7). Symmetry codes: (i) -x + 1, -y, -z; (ii) -y + 1/3, x - y - 1/3, z - 1/3.

elements.content: The dimeric fragment is centrosymmetric and is made of two Cu(II) atoms bridged by four adeninate anions in a windmill-shaped arrangement with a Cu1···Cu1i distance of 2.938(2) Å. The dihedral angle between the mean plane of the two crystallographically independent bridges (a and b) is 76.5(2)°. The basal positions of the distorted square-pyramidal coordination around the Cu(1) atom are occupied by two imidazole N9x atoms and two pyrimidinic N3x atoms of the deprotonated adeninate ligands with regular Cu−N bond distances of about 2.00 Å. The metal atom is displaced by 0.264(1) Å from this plane toward an apical coordinated water molecule at 2.172(6) Å. These structural parameters are similar to those reported for the dimeric compounds [Cu2(μ-Hade)4Cl2]Cl2·6H2O, [Cu2(μ-Hade)4(H2O)2](ClO4)2·2H2O, and [Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2]·2H2O containing μ-N3,N9 bridging ligands. Each dimeric fragment is linked to four neighboring monomeric entities via the N7x atom from the imidazole ring of the adeninate ligands with bond distances of Cu2−N7aii = 1.985(7) Å and Cu2−N7b = 1.997(7) Å.
elements.clean_text: The dimeric fragment is centrosymmetric and is made of two Cu(II) atoms bridged by four adeninate anions in a windmill-shaped arrangement with a Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu1i distance of 2.938(2) Å. The dihedral angle between the mean plane of the two crystallographically independent bridges (a and b) is 76.5(2)°. The basal positions of the distorted square-pyramidal coordination around the Cu(1) atom are occupied by two imidazole N9x atoms and two pyrimidinic N3x atoms of the deprotonated adeninate ligands with regular Cu-N bond distances of about 2.00 Å. The metal atom is displaced by 0.264(1) Å from this plane toward an apical coordinated water molecule at 2.172(6) Å. These structural parameters are similar to those reported for the dimeric compounds [Cu2(μ-Hade)4Cl2]Cl2⋅6H2O, [Cu2(μ-Hade)4(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅2H2O, and [Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2]⋅2H2O containing μ-N3,N9 bridging ligands. Each dimeric fragment is linked to four neighboring monomeric entities via the N7x atom from the imidazole ring of the adeninate ligands with bond distances of Cu2-N7aii = 1.985(7) Å and Cu2-N7b = 1.997(7) Å.

elements.content: Therefore, adeninate anions behave as tridentate μ-N3,N7,N9 bridging ligands. To our knowledge, this unusual coordination mode of the adenine has been reported only for some methylmercury(II) metalated adeninato(1−) derivatives, but it has been also observed in some complexes of the inmunosuppressant thiopurine drug azathioprine. Another tridentate coordination mode (μ-1κN9:2κ2N6,N7) has been reported for the adeninate bridging ligand in organometallic tetrameric Cp*Ir(III) and (p-cymene)Ru(II) complexes, but in these cases, the nucleobase is chelated to one metal by the imidazole N7 atom and the exocyclic N6 amino group to give a five-membered ring, whereas in compound 1, the amino groups remain uncoordinated and are hydrogen bonded to oxygen atoms.
elements.clean_text: Therefore, adeninate anions behave as tridentate μ-N3,N7,N9 bridging ligands. To our knowledge, this unusual coordination mode of the adenine has been reported only for some methylmercury(II) metalated adeninato(1-) derivatives, but it has been also observed in some complexes of the inmunosuppressant thiopurine drug azathioprine. Another tridentate coordination mode (μ-1κN9:2κ2N6,N7) has been reported for the adeninate bridging ligand in organometallic tetrameric Cp*Ir(III) and (p-cymene)Ru(II) complexes, but in these cases, the nucleobase is chelated to one metal by the imidazole N7 atom and the exocyclic N6 amino group to give a five-membered ring, whereas in compound 1, the amino groups remain uncoordinated and are hydrogen bonded to oxygen atoms.

elements.content: The basal plane of the square-pyramidal chromophore around the Cu2 atom is completed by two oxygen atoms from a bidentate oxalato ligand. The Cu2 atom is displaced by 0.152(1) Å from the basal plane toward the apical water molecule at 2.317(7) Å. The Cu1···Cu2 distance [5.857(4) Å] is similar to those reported for the dimer [Cu2(NBzIDA)2(μ-Hade)(H2O)2]·3H2O [5.926(1) Å, NBzIDA is the N-benzyliminodiacetato dianion] and for the 1D complex {[Cu(μ-purine)(H2O)4]SO4·2H2O} n [5.956(1) Å]12 in which the purine nucleobases show a similar bidentate μ-N7,N9 bridging coordination mode.
elements.clean_text: The basal plane of the square-pyramidal chromophore around the Cu2 atom is completed by two oxygen atoms from a bidentate oxalato ligand. The Cu2 atom is displaced by 0.152(1) Å from the basal plane toward the apical water molecule at 2.317(7) Å. The Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 distance [5.857(4) Å] is similar to those reported for the dimer [Cu2(NBzIDA)2(μ-Hade)(H2O)2]⋅3H2O [5.926(1) Å, NBzIDA is the N-benzyliminodiacetato dianion] and for the 1D complex {[Cu(μ-purine)(H2O)4]SO4⋅2H2O} n  [5.956(1) Å]12 in which the purine nucleobases show a similar bidentate μ-N7,N9 bridging coordination mode.

elements.content: The self-assembly process directed by the metal−adeninate linkages creates nanotubular channels along the crystallographic c axis with a diameter of about 13 Å, as shown in Figure . Calculations using PLATON showed that the effective volume for inclusion is greater than 4916 Å3/cell, comprising 40.4% of the crystal volume. Many guest water molecules are trapped in the parallel tubes. The solvated water molecules are engaged themselves and anchored to the inner walls of the nanotubes essentially via hydrogen bonds involving the coordinated water molecules, the uncoordinated oxygen oxalato atoms, and the amino groups of the adeninato bridges.
elements.clean_text: The self-assembly process directed by the metal-adeninate linkages creates nanotubular channels along the crystallographic c axis with a diameter of about 13 Å, as shown in Figure . Calculations using PLATON showed that the effective volume for inclusion is greater than 4916 Å3/cell, comprising 40.4% of the crystal volume. Many guest water molecules are trapped in the parallel tubes. The solvated water molecules are engaged themselves and anchored to  the inner walls of the nanotubes essentially via hydrogen bonds involving the coordinated water molecules, the uncoordinated oxygen oxalato atoms, and the amino groups of the adeninato bridges.

elements.content: Perspective view of the 3D framework along thec axis, showing the nanopores. Solvated water molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Perspective view of the 3D framework along thec axis, showing the nanopores. Solvated water molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Thermal degradation of compound 1 starts with an initial well-separated weight loss of 18.6%, between 40 and 95 °C, corresponding to the loss of 14 solvated water molecules per formula unit (calcd 19.5%). The large crystals do not change their external morphology during their dehydration, and the XRPD pattern of hydrated and dehydrated samples of 1 do not differ substantially, suggesting that the 3D framework structure is maintained after the crystallization water molecules are removed (see Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: Thermal degradation of compound 1 starts with an initial well-separated weight loss of 18.6%, between 40 and 95 °C, corresponding to the loss of 14 solvated water molecules per formula unit (calcd 19.5%). The large crystals do not change their external morphology during their dehydration, and the XRPD pattern of hydrated and dehydrated samples of 1 do not differ substantially, suggesting that the 3D framework structure is maintained after the crystallization water molecules are removed (see Supporting Information).

elements.content: Plots showing the thermal evolution of the magnetic molar susceptibility and the product χM T are presented in Figure (T range, 5−300 K; applied field, 1000 G). The room-temperature χM T value (1.41 cm3 mol-1 K) is lower than that expected for four uncoupled Cu(II) ions (1.50 cm3 mol-1 K, considering g = 2.00) and decreases rapidly upon cooling to 70 K, reaching a plateau with a value of 0.85 cm3 mol-1 K. Below 40 K, the curve decreases again to 0.66 cm3 mol-1 K at 5 K, which is lower than the value corresponding to the presence of two uncoupled Cu(II) atoms (0.75 cm3 mol-1 K, g = 2.00). A priori, the magnetic behavior of this compound must be dominated by the presence of two magnetic exchange pathways, one resulting from the four Cu1−N3−C4−N9−Cu1i bridges in the dimeric core and the other from the imidazole bridges that link the dimeric and four adjacent monomeric entities. For the first pathway, singlet−triplet energy gap (J) values near −300 cm-1 have been reported for the complexes [Cu2(μ-Hade)4Cl2]Cl2·6H2O, [Cu2(μ-Hade)4(H2O)2] (ClO4)2·2H2O, and [Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2]·2H2O. With respect to the superexchange magnetic coupling through bidentate μ-N7,N9 purine nucleobases, to date, the available magnetic data for complexes based on this type of bridge indicate very weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the Cu(II) ions.
elements.clean_text: Plots showing the thermal evolution of the magnetic molar susceptibility and the product χM T are presented in Figure  (T range, 5-300 K; applied field, 1000 G). The room-temperature χM T value (1.41 cm3 mol-1 K) is lower than that expected for four uncoupled Cu(II) ions (1.50 cm3 mol-1 K, considering g = 2.00) and decreases rapidly upon cooling to 70 K, reaching a plateau with a value of 0.85 cm3 mol-1 K. Below 40 K, the curve decreases again to 0.66 cm3 mol-1 K at 5 K, which is lower than the value corresponding to the presence of two uncoupled Cu(II) atoms (0.75 cm3 mol-1 K, g = 2.00). A priori, the magnetic behavior of this compound must be dominated by the presence of two magnetic exchange pathways, one resulting from the four Cu1-N3-C4-N9-Cu1i bridges in the dimeric core and the other from the imidazole bridges that link the dimeric and four adjacent monomeric entities. For the first pathway, singlet-triplet energy gap (J) values near -300 cm-1 have been reported for the complexes [Cu2(μ-Hade)4Cl2]Cl2⋅6H2O, [Cu2(μ-Hade)4(H2O)2] (ClO4)2⋅2H2O, and [Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2]⋅2H2O. With respect to the superexchange magnetic coupling through bidentate μ-N7,N9 purine nucleobases, to date, the available magnetic data for complexes based on this type of bridge indicate very weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the Cu(II) ions.

elements.content: Thermal dependence of the χM (○) and χM T (·) curves for compound 1. Continuous lines correspond to the best least-squares fit of the high-temperature data (T > 30 K).
elements.clean_text: 3  Thermal dependence of the χM (○) and χM T (⋅) curves for compound 1. Continuous lines correspond to the best least-squares fit of the high-temperature data (T > 30 K).

elements.content: From a structural viewpoint, the title compound exhibits a 3D framework, but keeping in mind the capacity of the bridges to transmit magnetic interactions and the overall appearance of the χM T curve, we tried to fit the experimental magnetic data by using the Bleaney−Bowers equation (H = −JS 1 S 2) for a dinuclear copper(II) complex, modified to take into account the presence of one dimeric and two monomeric copper entities per formula unit. No reasonable fit could be obtained over the whole experimental curve, but by taking into account only the data above 30 K, a relatively good fit could be achieved (solid lines in Figure ) with the parameters J = −316 cm-1, g d = 2.11, and g m = 2.10. g d and g m are the mean g factors for the copper(II) ions of the dimeric and monomeric fragments, respectively. Even if the fit is not completely satisfactory, the calculated J value is in good agreement with the structural characteristics, and it can be considered as a rather good approximation. The discrepancy between experimental and calculated data at lower temperatures suggests that the participation of the imidazole bridges in the magnetic exchange between the dimeric (Cu1) and monomeric (Cu2) entities cannot be a priori disregarded.
elements.clean_text: From a structural viewpoint, the title compound exhibits a 3D framework, but keeping in mind the capacity of the bridges to transmit magnetic interactions and the overall appearance of the χM T curve, we tried to fit the experimental magnetic data by using the Bleaney-Bowers equation (H = -JS 1 S 2) for a dinuclear copper(II) complex, modified to take into account the presence of one dimeric and two monomeric copper entities per formula unit. No reasonable fit could be obtained over the whole experimental curve, but by taking into account only the data above 30 K, a relatively good fit could be achieved (solid lines in Figure ) with the parameters J = -316 cm-1, g d = 2.11, and g m = 2.10. g d and g m are the mean g factors for the copper(II) ions of the dimeric and monomeric fragments, respectively. Even if the fit is not completely satisfactory, the calculated J value is in good agreement with the structural characteristics, and it can be considered as a rather good approximation. The discrepancy between experimental and calculated data at lower temperatures suggests that the participation of the imidazole bridges in the magnetic exchange between the dimeric (Cu1) and monomeric (Cu2) entities cannot be a priori disregarded.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format, FT-IR spectra, TGA/DTA curves, variable-temperature XRPD patterns, and ORTEP views. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format, FT-IR spectra, TGA/DTA curves, variable-temperature XRPD patterns, and ORTEP views. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
The first 3D coordination polymer containing a nucleobase as a bridging ligand, {[Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2][Cu(ox)(H2O)]2·∼14H2O} n (1), has been synthesized by reaction of adenine (Hade) with a basic solution of K2[Cu(ox)2]·2H2O (ox = oxalato dianion). Compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̄ with a = b = 31.350(1) Å, c = 14.285(1) Å, V = 12158.7(10) Å3, and Z = 9. X-ray analysis shows a covalent 3D network in which the copper(II) centers are bridged by tridentate μ-N3,N7,N9 adeninate ligands. The compound has relatively large, nanometer-sized tubes associated with the self-assembly process directed solely by metal−ligand interactions. The covalent 3D framework remains intact upon removal of the guest water molecules trapped in the nanotubes. Magnetic measurements indicate an overall antiferromagnetic behavior of the compound.

Thermal degradation of compound 1 starts with an initial well-separated weight loss of 18.6%, between 40 and 95 °C, corresponding to the loss of 14 solvated water molecules per formula unit (calcd 19.5%). The large crystals do not change their external morphology during their dehydration, and the XRPD pattern of hydrated and dehydrated samples of 1 do not differ substantially, suggesting that the 3D framework structure is maintained after the crystallization water molecules are removed (see Supporting Information).
cln_elements.clean_text:
The first 3D coordination polymer containing a nucleobase as a bridging ligand, {[Cu2(μ-ade)4(H2O)2][Cu(ox)(H2O)]2⋅~14H2O} n  (1), has been synthesized by reaction of adenine (Hade) with a basic solution of K2[Cu(ox)2]⋅2H2O (ox = oxalato dianion). Compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̄ with a = b = 31.350(1) Å, c = 14.285(1) Å, V = 12158.7(10) Å3, and Z = 9. X-ray analysis shows a covalent 3D network in which the copper(II) centers are bridged by tridentate μ-N3,N7,N9 adeninate ligands. The compound has relatively large, nanometer-sized tubes associated with the self-assembly process directed solely by metal-ligand interactions. The covalent 3D framework remains intact upon removal of the guest water molecules trapped in the nanotubes. Magnetic measurements indicate an overall antiferromagnetic behavior of the compound. 

Thermal degradation of compound 1 starts with an initial well-separated weight loss of 18.6%, between 40 and 95 °C, corresponding to the loss of 14 solvated water molecules per formula unit (calcd 19.5%). The large crystals do not change their external morphology during their dehydration, and the XRPD pattern of hydrated and dehydrated samples of 1 do not differ substantially, suggesting that the 3D framework structure is maintained after the crystallization water molecules are removed (see Supporting Information).

metadata.title:
An Unusual 3D Coordination Polymer Based on Bridging Interactions of
the Nucleobase Adenine
